section.title: Easily Confused Words
section.para: This section identifies some easily confused words and how to choose the correct term for your situation.

formalpara.title: Affect and Effect
formalpara.para: Each of these words can be used as a verb or a noun, but they are not always interchangeable.

listitem.para: As a noun, refers to the emotional impact of an action. Unless you are writing a psychology article, this is unlikely to be the choice for you.
As a verb, means to have an influence on something, or to cause something to change.
As a noun, refers to the result of some action. For example, "the team members discussed the effect of the new policy on their working conditions."
As a verb, means to produce a result, or to cause something to happen. For example, "the CEO claimed that the new policy would effect a positive economic outcome."

The use of "effect" as a verb is less common than the use of "affect," and there are usually alternatives that are clearer. For example, "the CEO claimed that the new policy would produce a positive economic outcome."

formalpara.title: Assure, Ensure, and Insure
formalpara.para: These are relatively easy to get right, but here are some quick definitions.

listitem.para: "Assure" suggests mental comfort. For example, "I assured my future father-in-law that I would eventually find a job."
"Ensure" means to make sure of something, to be certain that something exists or some condition has been met.
